Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an Automated TL/OSL Luminescence Reader, Gamma Spectrometer, and Portable Field Gamma Spectrometer for the Dating of Sedimentary and Archaeological Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
1337254
Sammeth

This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) Program grant supports the acquisition of an optically stimulated luminescence (OSL) and thermoluminescence reader and associated gamma ray spectrometer to support research and undergraduate education at New Mexico Highlands University, a non-Ph.D granting institution. The OSL lab at NMHU will support research that will benefit from the ability to date the burial ages of silicate phases in geological and archaeological materials up to several hundreds of thousands years before present. The instrument will support Quaternary investigations of the timing and extent of past glaciations and subsequent retreat and the influence of past climate on plant and animal life and human evolution and distribution. The OSL lab will be the first of its kind in the state of New Mexico and will support experiential laboratory training for a student population dominated by Hispanic students. The NMHU OSL lab will serve researchers and students across the departments of Forestry, Environmental Geology, Chemistry, Biology, and Anthropology and will support national and international collaborations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Thermoluminescence and optically stimulated luminescence (TL/OSL) are experimental techniques used in the field of dosimetry, which is the measurement and calculation of the radiation dose received by matter resulting from the exposure to ionizing radiation. It has applications in variety of fields which include medicine, national security, geology, archeology and environmental studies. A scientific sub-specialty of the field is focused on the dating of materials based on the accumulation of natural radiation from the local environment. The material typically being dated is either quartz or feldspar; two of the most common minerals on earth. The measurement of absorbed radiation currently held by the mineral grain is correlated to the time since the quartz was last exposed to sunlight or sufficient heat. For example, a sample obtained from the base of a sand dune and dated by OSL would measure the period of time since that sample was deposited by Aeolian (wind) transport, or in the case of an excavation, the period of time since that material was removed by a backhoe.

 A Risø TL/OSL Luminescence Dating System and a Canberra Gamma Ray Spectrometer have been purchased and installed in the New Mexico Highlands University’s Luminescence Dating Laboratory. This equipment allows for the dating of sedimentary and archaeological materials. TL/OSL is a dating method that permits determination of the calendar ages ranging from years to several hundred thousand years. Luminescence dating requires only the presence of common feldspar or quartz in the sample. The TL/OSL Luminescence Reader is be used to determine the equivalent dose of the sample (amount of total energy absorbed by the quartz sample) and the Gamma Ray Spectrometer is used measure the dose rate (the amount of energy striking the quartz sample per year), thereby providing the age of the sample: age = equiv. dose/dose rate.

The New Mexico Highlands facility is the only luminescence dating lab in the state of New Mexico. In addition to providing dating services, the lab will also emphasis theoretical and experimental investigation of luminescence dosimetry as applied to geological and archaeological dating in order to improve existing techniques and theoretical models. Current projects include the study of natural and synthetically prepared quartz by TL/OSL and single crystal X-ray diffraction as a method of exploring the chemical and physical basis of TL/OSL dating, the dating of a mammoth site in North-East New Mexico, and the dating of historical buildings in Santa Fe in collaboration the Santa Fe Historical Society.
